Provide comprehensive DEI training programs that educate employees on topics such as unconscious bias, inclusive leadership, cross-cultural communication, and allyship. These trainings should be tailored to different employee levels, from frontline staff to executives, and be reinforced through ongoing learning opportunities.


Foster Employee Resource Groups (ERGs)


Encourage the formation of employee resource groups that bring together individuals with shared identities, experiences, or interests. ERGs can serve as valuable platforms for community building, mentorship, advocacy, and professional development, further strengthening a sense of belonging and inclusion.


Measure and Communicate Progress


Regularly track and measure the impact of your DEI initiatives, using both quantitative and qualitative metrics. Share progress updates and successes with your employees, celebrating milestones and reinforcing the importance of this work. Solicit feedback from your workforce and continuously refine your strategies based on evolving needs and challenges.

Estate Planning Strategies for High-Net-Worth Families in Dallas


When it comes to safeguarding the financial legacies of high-net-worth families in Dallas, a comprehensive estate plan is essential. With a team of adept attorneys, Haley, Bailey & Jones navigates complex legal matters with precision and empathy, ensuring that clients receive strategic counsel and effective representation across a range of practice areas.


Establishing Trusts for Asset Protection and Tax Minimization




Trusts are a popular estate planning tool in Dallas because they allow assets to pass directly to beneficiaries upon the death of the settlor without the need for probate. This can save time and money and help to protect assets from creditors and legal challenges. Additionally, trusts can be used to provide for specific beneficiaries, such as minor children or disabled adults.


One strategy for high-net-worth families is the Grantor Retained Annuity Trust (GRAT), which allows the grantor to transfer assets to beneficiaries with minimal gift and estate tax consequences. The grantor contributes assets to the trust but retains the right to receive an annuity from the trust, while the appreciation of the assets over the set §7520 rate goes to the designated beneficiaries.


Implementing Comprehensive Asset Protection Strategies




Safeguarding one's wealth is a top priority for high-net-worth families in Dallas. In addition to trusts, other asset protection strategies can include appointing a durable power of attorney (POA) and a healthcare power of attorney (HCPA). A durable POA allows an agent to manage financial and legal matters, including property, after the individual becomes incapacitated. A HCPA, on the other hand, empowers an agent to make medical decisions on the individual's behalf.


By incorporating these strategies into a comprehensive estate plan, high-net-worth families can ensure their assets are protected and their wishes are carried out, even in the event of incapacity or death.


Navigating Complex Family Dynamics and Succession Planning




High-net-worth families in Dallas often face unique challenges when it comes to estate planning, such as blended family structures, complex business interests, and multi-generational wealth. To address these complexities, Haley, Bailey & Jones works closely with clients to develop customized estate plans that take into account their specific needs and goals.

At Haley, Bailey & Jones, our team of experienced estate planning attorneys is dedicated to providing comprehensive legal services tailored to the diverse needs of high-net-worth families in Dallas. Divorce and Family Law: Navigating the Complexities in Dallas


Navigating the intricate legal landscape of divorce and family law can be a daunting experience, especially for those unfamiliar with the nuances of the Texas legal system. In the bustling city of Dallas, where life moves at a rapid pace, the need for skilled legal representation becomes paramount. From the equitable division of assets to the sensitive matters of child custody and support, the complexities of family law require the guidance of seasoned professionals.




Divorce, a life-altering event, can leave individuals feeling overwhelmed and unsure of their rights and obligations. Whether you are facing a contested or uncontested divorce, the outcome can have far-reaching consequences on your financial well-being and the future of your family. It is crucial to seek the counsel of an experienced Dallas divorce attorney who can navigate the complex legal procedures and advocate for your best interests.


Understanding the Intricacies of Texas Divorce Law




The state of Texas follows a unique approach to divorce and property division, known as the "community property" system. Under this system, assets and debts accumulated during the marriage are considered jointly owned, and the court must divide them in a "just and right" manner. This can involve intricate calculations and negotiations, particularly when dealing with high-net-worth individuals or complex asset structures.


In addition to the equitable division of property, the court must also address critical issues such as child custody, visitation rights, and child support. Texas law emphasizes the best interests of the child, and judges must carefully weigh factors like the child's well-being, the parents' ability to provide a stable home, and the child's preferences (if age-appropriate). Navigating these sensitive matters requires a deep understanding of family law and a compassionate approach to ensure the well-being of all parties involved.


Dealing with Custody and Support Disputes




Child custody and support disputes can be among the most contentious aspects of a divorce. Texas courts generally favor joint custody arrangements, where both parents share the rights and responsibilities of raising the child. However, in cases where one parent is deemed unfit or a danger to the child, the court may award sole custody to the other parent. Understanding the nuances of child custody laws and the factors considered by the court is crucial for securing the best possible outcome for your family.


Child support determinations are also complex, as they involve calculations based on the parents' incomes, the number of children, and other factors. An experienced family law attorney can ensure that the child support order is fair and accurate, protecting the interests of both the custodial and non-custodial parent. In cases where modifications or enforcement of child support are necessary, legal counsel is essential to navigate the legal process.


Navigating the Emotional Toll of Divorce

Navigating Probate Law: A Comprehensive Guide for Executors in Texas


Losing a loved one is a profoundly difficult experience, and the legal complexities of probate can add an additional layer of stress during an already challenging time. As an executor, navigating the intricacies of probate law in Texas can feel overwhelming. However, with the right guidance and understanding of the process, you can effectively manage the estate and honor your loved one's wishes.


Understanding Probate in Texas




Probate is the legal process of administering the estate of a deceased person, including the distribution of their assets and the payment of their debts and taxes. In Texas, the probate process can vary depending on the size and complexity of the estate, as well as the presence or absence of a will.


If the deceased individual had a valid will, the probate process typically involves the court appointing an executor named in the will to oversee the administration of the estate. If there is no will, the court will appoint an administrator, often a close family member, to manage the estate.


The probate process in Texas generally involves the following steps:


  1. Filing the Will - The will must be filed with the appropriate probate court, usually in the county where the deceased individual resided.
  2. Appointment of an Executor - If the deceased had a will, the court will appoint the named executor to oversee the administration of the estate. If there is no will, the court will appoint an administrator.
  3. Inventory and Appraisal - The executor or administrator must compile a comprehensive inventory of the deceased's assets and liabilities, as well as have the assets appraised.
  4. Notice to Creditors - The executor or administrator must provide notice to known creditors of the deceased's estate, allowing them to file claims against the estate.
  5. Payment of Debts and Taxes - The executor or administrator must use the estate's assets to pay any outstanding debts and taxes owed by the deceased.
  6. Distribution of Assets - Once all debts and taxes have been paid, the remaining assets are distributed to the beneficiaries named in the will or, in the absence of a will, to the deceased's legal heirs.

Responsibilities of an Executor




As an executor, you have a fiduciary duty to the estate and its beneficiaries, which means you must act in their best interests and with the utmost care and diligence. Some of the key responsibilities of an executor in Texas include:


  • Locating and Securing Assets - You must identify, locate, and secure all of the deceased's assets, including bank accounts, real estate, investments, and personal property.
  • Paying Debts and Taxes - You are responsible for paying any outstanding debts and taxes owed by the estate, including estate taxes, if applicable.
  • Distributing Assets - You must ensure that the deceased's assets are distributed to the named beneficiaries or legal heirs according to the terms of the will or, in the absence of a will, Texas intestacy laws.
  • Keeping Accurate Records - You must maintain detailed records of all transactions and decisions made on behalf of the estate.
  • Filing Required Documents - You must file various legal documents with the probate court, including the initial application for probate, inventories, and accountings.

It's important to note that the role of an executor can be complex and time-consuming, and it's crucial to seek the guidance of an experienced probate attorney to ensure that you fulfill your duties properly and protect the interests of the estate and its beneficiaries.


Avoiding Common Probate Pitfalls




Navigating the probate process can be challenging, and there are several common pitfalls that executors should be aware of and try to avoid:


  • Failing to Properly Inventory Assets - Overlooking or misidentifying assets can lead to complications in the distribution of the estate.
  • Untimely Filing of Documents - Failing to file required documents with the probate court within the specified timeframes can result in penalties or even the removal of the executor.
  • Improper Allocation of Assets - Distributing assets in a way that contradicts the terms of the will or Texas intestacy laws can lead to legal disputes and challenges.
  • Failing to Properly Notify Creditors - Not providing adequate notice to creditors can leave the executor personally liable for unpaid debts.

Navigating Family Law: Understanding Child Custody in Texas

In Texas, we use the term 'conservatorship' instead of custody. There are two types: joint managing conservatorship (JMC) and sole managing conservatorship (SMC). JMC is the most common, where both parents share rights and duties, though one parent usually has the exclusive right to decide the child's primary residence.


It's crucial to understand that conservatorship is different from possession and access (visitation). Even in a JMC arrangement, one parent might have significantly more time with the child than the other.


Texas courts always prioritize the best interest of the child when making custody decisions. Factors considered include the child's physical and emotional needs, each parent's ability to care for the child, and the child's preference if they're 12 or older.

Implications of Driving Without Insurance in Missouri

Driving without insurance in Missouri is not just a risky decision; it's a violation of state law that can lead to severe consequences. As a responsible driver, understanding the implications of this offense is crucial for maintaining your legal standing and financial security on the road.

Legal Requirements for Auto Insurance in Missouri

Missouri law mandates that all motorists carry a minimum level of auto insurance. According to the Missouri Department of Revenue, the required coverage includes:

Coverage Type

Minimum Amount

Bodily Injury Liability

$25,000 per person / $50,000 per accident

Property Damage Liability

$25,000 per accident

These requirements ensure that drivers have at least basic protection in case of accidents, covering potential injuries to others and damage to their property.

Penalties for Driving Uninsured

The consequences of driving without insurance in Missouri can be severe and far-reaching. If caught, uninsured drivers may face:

1. License Suspension: Your driving privileges could be revoked for up to one year.

2. Hefty Fines: A fine of up to $500 may be imposed.

3. Possible Jail Time: Repeat offenders might face up to 15 days in jail.

4. Reinstatement Fees: To regain your driving privileges, you'll need to pay a $400 reinstatement fee.

5. Points on Driving Record: Each conviction adds four points to your driving record, potentially leading to further license suspension or revocation.

Financial Implications Beyond Legal Penalties

The repercussions of driving without insurance extend beyond legal penalties. Uninsured drivers face significant financial risks:

1. Personal Liability: In the event of an accident, you'll be personally responsible for all damages and injuries, which can lead to substantial out-of-pocket expenses or even bankruptcy.

2. Legal Costs: If sued by other parties involved in an accident, you'll need to cover your own legal defense costs.

3. Higher Future Premiums: Once you do obtain insurance, your rates are likely to be much higher due to your history of driving uninsured.

4. Limited Recourse: If you're involved in an accident with another uninsured driver, you may have little legal recourse to recover damages.

Impact on Other Drivers

Driving without insurance doesn't just affect the uninsured individual; it has broader implications for all Missouri drivers. According to the Missouri Department of Revenue, uninsured drivers contribute to:

1. Higher Insurance Rates: The cost of uninsured motorist claims is spread across all insured drivers, leading to higher premiums for everyone.

2. Increased Financial Burden: Insured drivers may have to rely on their own uninsured motorist coverage in accidents with uninsured drivers, potentially increasing their out-of-pocket expenses.

3. Strain on Public Resources: Accidents involving uninsured drivers can lead to unpaid medical bills and property damage claims, putting a strain on public services and healthcare systems.

Alternatives to Driving Uninsured

If you're struggling to afford auto insurance, there are alternatives to consider before risking driving uninsured:

1. Shop Around: Compare quotes from multiple insurers to find the most affordable coverage.

2. Increase Deductibles: Opting for higher deductibles can lower your premiums.

3. Explore Discounts: Many insurers offer discounts for safe driving, bundling policies, or completing defensive driving courses.

4. Consider Usage-Based Insurance: Some companies offer lower rates based on your actual driving habits.

5. Public Transportation: In some cases, utilizing public transit or carpooling may be more cost-effective than maintaining a vehicle and insurance.

Driving without insurance in Missouri carries significant legal, financial, and social implications. The risks far outweigh any perceived short-term savings. It's crucial to prioritize maintaining proper insurance coverage not only to comply with state law but also to protect yourself and others on the road.

If you're facing charges related to driving without insurance or need assistance understanding your legal options, don't hesitate to seek professional help. E1 Visa Concurrent Employment: Navigating Multiple Work Opportunities

The E1 visa, also known as the Treaty Trader visa, offers unique opportunities for international businesspeople engaged in substantial trade between their home country and the United States. While the primary purpose of this visa is to facilitate trade, many visa holders wonder about the possibility of concurrent employment. In this comprehensive guide, we'll explore the intricacies of E1 visa concurrent employment, its limitations, and what you need to know to stay compliant with U.S. immigration laws.

Understanding the E1 Visa Basics

Before delving into concurrent employment, it's crucial to understand the fundamental aspects of the E1 visa:

Purpose: The E1 visa is designed for individuals from countries with which the United States maintains a treaty of commerce and navigation. It allows these individuals to enter the U.S. to engage in substantial international trade on their own behalf.

Eligibility: To qualify for an E1 visa, the applicant must be a national of a treaty country and be involved in substantial trade, principally between the U.S. and the treaty country.

Duration: Initially granted for up to two years, the E1 visa can be extended indefinitely as long as the holder maintains eligibility.

The Concept of Concurrent Employment

Concurrent employment refers to working for multiple employers simultaneously. For many visa categories, this concept is straightforward, but for E1 visa holders, the situation is more nuanced.

E1 Visa Employment Restrictions

E1 visa holders are generally restricted to working only for the specific employer or self-owned business that acted as their E1 visa sponsor. This limitation is in place to ensure that the primary purpose of the visa – facilitating international trade – is maintained.

However, the concept of "employment" under the E1 visa is broader than traditional employment relationships. It encompasses the treaty trader's activities in operating their business or representing the treaty organization.

Potential for Concurrent Activities

While direct employment with multiple unrelated companies is generally not permitted, E1 visa holders may engage in various activities that could be considered forms of concurrent employment:

1. Multiple Trade Ventures: An E1 visa holder can engage in multiple trade ventures, as long as they all contribute to the substantial trade between the U.S. and the treaty country.

2. Consulting Services: Providing consulting services to multiple clients, as long as these services are related to the primary trade activities.

3. Subsidiary or Affiliate Companies: Working for subsidiary or affiliate companies of the primary E1 sponsoring organization may be permissible, provided the work aligns with the original visa purpose.

Navigating the Grey Areas

The interpretation of what constitutes permissible concurrent activities can sometimes fall into grey areas. Here are some key considerations:

Consideration

Explanation

Nature of Activities

Must be related to international trade

Primary Purpose

Must not deviate from original visa intent

Substantial Trade

Activities should contribute to trade volume

Best Practices for E1 Visa Holders

If you're an E1 visa holder considering engaging in activities that might be construed as concurrent employment, consider these best practices:

1. Consult an Immigration Attorney: Before undertaking any additional business activities, seek advice from an experienced immigration attorney who can evaluate your specific situation.

2. Maintain Detailed Records: Keep comprehensive records of all your business activities to demonstrate that they align with your E1 visa purpose.

3. Notify USCIS of Significant Changes: If there are substantial changes to your business activities, it may be necessary to inform U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS).

4. Focus on Trade Expansion: Any additional activities should ideally contribute to expanding the trade between the U.S. and your treaty country.

5. Avoid Traditional Employment Relationships: Steer clear of taking on roles that resemble traditional employment with companies unrelated to your E1 activities.

The Importance of Compliance

Maintaining compliance with E1 visa regulations is crucial. Engaging in unauthorized employment can lead to severe consequences, including visa revocation and potential bars on future entry to the United States. It's always better to err on the side of caution and seek professional guidance when in doubt.

Looking Ahead: Potential Changes and Alternatives

As immigration policies evolve, it's essential to stay informed about potential changes that might affect E1 visa holders. Understanding Fraud and Forgery in Estate Matters

Fraud in estate matters can take various forms, including misrepresentation, concealment of assets, or the unauthorized transfer of property. Forgery, on the other hand, involves the creation or alteration of legal documents, such as wills or trusts, without proper authorization. These acts not only violate the law but also undermine the decedent's wishes and deprive rightful beneficiaries of their inheritance.

Fraud and forgery can occur at various stages of the estate planning and probate process in Texas. In some cases, individuals may attempt to exert undue influence over the decedent, coercing them into altering their estate plan or signing documents against their true wishes. Alternatively, fraudsters may forge signatures or create entirely fictitious documents purporting to represent the decedent's final wishes. These deceptive practices can have far-reaching consequences, causing rifts within families and breeding mistrust among loved ones.

It's important to be vigilant for any signs of fraud or forgery, such as sudden changes to estate plans, unexplained transfers of assets, or the involvement of individuals with questionable motives. Paying close attention to the decedent's mental state and ensuring their wishes are accurately documented can help prevent such fraudulent acts from occurring in the first place.

Legal Remedies for Recovering Property in Texas

When property has been taken from an estate through fraud or forgery in Texas, there are several legal avenues available to recover those assets. One common remedy is to initiate a will contest or trust contest, challenging the validity of the documents in question. If successful, the court may set aside the fraudulent document and restore the rightful distribution of the estate.

In cases where assets have already been distributed, beneficiaries may pursue legal action against the individuals responsible for the fraud or forgery. Another potential avenue is to seek the appointment of a temporary administrator or receiver to take control of the estate assets until the matter is resolved. This can help prevent further dissipation of assets and ensure their preservation during the legal proceedings.

What Happens If You Try to Get a Power of Attorney After a Person Has Dementia?

As the population ages, the prevalence of dementia and related cognitive impairments continues to rise. This brings about unique legal challenges, particularly concerning decision-making authority and the management of personal affairs. One of the most crucial documents in such situations is the power of attorney (POA). But what happens if you try to obtain a POA after a loved one has already developed dementia?



The Importance of Legal Capacity

To grant a valid POA, the individual (known as the "principal") must possess the legal capacity to understand the nature and consequences of the document they're signing. This means they must comprehend the authority they're granting to their designated agent (the "attorney-in-fact") and the potential ramifications of their decisions.

In the case of dementia, cognitive impairment can gradually erode an individual's ability to make reasoned decisions and appreciate the implications of their actions. As the condition progresses, there may come a point where the principal no longer retains the requisite mental capacity to execute a legally binding POA. This is why it's crucial to plan ahead and establish a POA before the onset of significant cognitive decline.

Assessing Mental Capacity

If there's any doubt about the principal's mental capacity, it's advisable to seek a formal assessment from a qualified medical professional. Various tests, such as the Hopkins Competency Assessment Test, can evaluate an individual's cognitive abilities and determine their capacity to grant a POA.



In some cases, the principal may still have sufficient capacity to execute a springing POA, which becomes effective only upon the occurrence of a specified event or condition, such as a finding of incapacity by a medical professional. This can provide a safeguard for the future while still allowing the principal to retain control in the present. However, it's essential to act promptly, as cognitive abilities can deteriorate rapidly with certain forms of dementia.

The Guardianship/Conservatorship Alternative

If the principal lacks the mental capacity to grant a POA, the family may need to pursue guardianship or conservatorship through the court system. This legal process involves appointing a guardian or conservator to make decisions on behalf of the incapacitated individual regarding their personal care, financial affairs, or both.

While guardianship/conservatorship offers a solution, it's generally more time-consuming, expensive, and intrusive than a POA. Additionally, the court may not necessarily appoint the individual preferred by the family, potentially leading to conflicts or decisions that diverge from the principal's wishes. This underscores the importance of establishing a POA proactively, while the principal still possesses the necessary mental capacity.

The Consequences of Inaction

Failing to establish a POA or seek guardianship/conservatorship can have severe consequences for individuals with dementia and their loved ones. Without a designated decision-maker, healthcare providers and financial institutions may be unable to discuss or manage the individual's affairs, leading to potential neglect, exploitation, or the depletion of assets.

Moreover, family members may find themselves embroiled in costly legal battles as they struggle to gain the authority to act in their loved one's best interests. These circumstances can further compound the emotional and financial strain already faced by families caring for individuals with dementia. In extreme cases, the court may appoint a professional guardian or conservator, further distancing the individual from their loved ones and potentially increasing costs.

Proactive planning is essential to avoid these challenges and ensure that an individual's wishes are respected, even in the face of cognitive decline. This often involves not only establishing a POA but also creating a comprehensive estate plan that includes advanced directives for healthcare, trusts for asset management, and other safeguards tailored to the individual's specific needs and preferences.

Navigating the Influencer-Brand Landscape: Legal Tips for Safeguarding Your Influence

In the rapidly evolving digital age, influencers have emerged as powerful voices shaping consumer trends and brand narratives. However, this newfound influence also comes with legal risks, especially when collaborating with big brands. As an influencer, protecting your personal brand, reputation, and legal standing is paramount. Here's a comprehensive guide to help you navigate the influencer-brand landscape and safeguard your influence.

Disclosure: The Cornerstone of Transparency

Transparency is the bedrock of influencer marketing, and failure to disclose sponsored content or endorsements can land you in legal hot water. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) requires clear and conspicuous disclosures when promoting products or services in exchange for compensation, whether monetary or otherwise. Neglecting these rules can result in hefty fines and damage your credibility with followers.

Disclosures should be prominent, unambiguous, and easily understood by the average consumer. The FTC recommends using clear language like "paid ad" or "sponsored" rather than vague hashtags or buried disclosures. Additionally, disclosures should be made at the beginning of your content, whether it's a video, blog post, or social media post, to ensure viewers are aware of the sponsored nature upfront.

Intellectual Property: Respecting Creative Rights

As an influencer, it's crucial to respect intellectual property rights, including trademarks, copyrights, and patents. Before using any brand's logos, slogans, or creative assets, ensure you have the necessary permissions. Unauthorized use can lead to costly infringement lawsuits and tarnish your reputation. Additionally, be cautious about using third-party content, such as images or music, without proper licensing.

Intellectual property laws are complex and vary across jurisdictions. It's best to consult with an intellectual property lawyer to understand the boundaries and obtain the necessary licenses or permissions. Failing to do so can result in legal action, financial penalties, and irreparable harm to your personal brand.

Contractual Obligations: Read the Fine Print

When entering into brand partnerships, carefully review the terms and conditions. Influencer contracts often include clauses related to exclusivity, content ownership, and termination provisions. Seek legal counsel to ensure you fully understand your rights and obligations, as well as the potential consequences of breaching the agreement.

Pay close attention to clauses that may restrict your ability to work with competing brands or limit your creative control over the content. Additionally, be wary of contracts that grant the brand ownership over the content you create, as this could limit your ability to repurpose or monetize your work in the future.

Privacy and Consent: Safeguarding Personal Information

As an influencer, you may inadvertently expose personal or sensitive information about your followers or collaborators. Respect individual privacy rights by obtaining proper consent before using names, images, or likenesses in your content. Additionally, be mindful of data protection regulations, such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), when handling personal information.

Failing to obtain consent or mishandling personal data can lead to legal consequences, including fines and lawsuits. Implement robust privacy policies and data protection measures to safeguard your audience's information and maintain their trust.

Authenticity and Credibility: Your Brand's Lifeline

In the influencer realm, authenticity and credibility are invaluable assets. Avoid making false or misleading claims about products or services, as this can violate consumer protection laws and erode your followers' trust. Always strive for transparency and disclose any biases or conflicts of interest that may influence your endorsements.

Maintain a high standard of ethics and integrity in your content creation and endorsements. Providing honest, unbiased reviews and recommendations will not only protect you from legal repercussions but also strengthen your credibility and rapport with your audience.

By prioritizing legal compliance, respecting intellectual property rights, and maintaining authenticity, you can protect your influence and foster long-lasting relationships with brands and your audience. Remember, as an influencer, your personal brand is your most valuable asset. Safeguarding it should be a top priority.

BIG_BLOG.TITLE: What Is Your Onset Date?
BIG_BLOG.CONTENT:
Long-Term Disability Insurance vs Short-Term Disability Insurance Explained
    by Amar Raval
    Dec 11, 2023
    Doctor touching shoulders of patient in a wheelchair. long term disability vs short term.
    You will not receive a Social Security disability check on the day that you become disabled. Instead, you will have to apply for Social Security disability benefits and part of the application will include proving when you became disabled. The date when you became disabled is known as your Social Security disability onset date.

    How to Establish a Disability Onset Date
    If you were hurt and became disabled as a result of a sudden accident, it may be easy to provide the date when your disability started. However, if you have a medical condition or illness, it might be more difficult to pinpoint the exact date on which you became disabled.
    
    The Social Security Administration (SSA) will consider the following factors in determining your onset date:
    
    The date that you designate as your alleged onset date on your Social Security disability application.
    The date on which you stopped working or stopped working enough to earn a significant income.
    Your doctor’s opinion as to when your disability began and you became unable to work.
    Your medical records.
    It is important that the onset date be accurate because you may be eligible to receive Social Security disability beginning five months after your established onset date. In some cases, you may be able to receive compensation for months when your Social Security disability application was pending.
    
    What If You Try to Work and You Are Unsuccessful?
    In some cases, people with disabilities will attempt to work after their onset dates of disability. Unfortunately, they may find that their health problems only allow them to work for brief periods of time. This is what SSA calls an “unsuccessful work attempt.”  An unsuccessful work attempt occurs after a “significant break” from the time you stopped working or reduced your work and earnings below substantial gainful activity levels. Generally, the SSA considers a significant break to be at least 30 consecutive days or when you are forced to change to another type of work or employer.
    
    You may be concerned that your unsuccessful work attempt will impact your disability onset date. However, if your work activity after your onset date of disability is considered an unsuccessful work attempt, it will not affect the date you alleged that you became disabled.
    
    There are so many factors to look at when trying to pin down which is the correct onset date of disability. That is why it is important to sit down with your attorney and to fully discuss these issues before deciding what date is appropriate.
    
    If you have questions about your established onset date or any other aspect of your Social Security disability application, please read our FREE report, Social Security Disability: What You Need to Know and start a live chat with us today.

BIG_BLOG.TITLE: Questions You Should Expect To Be Asked During A Social Security Disability Hearing
BIG_BLOG.CONTENT:
You never wanted to go to a hearing, but now that your Social Security disability application has been denied you are going to have to go to a hearing in order to get the benefits you deserve. You may be anxious about the process and curious about what you should expect. You deserve to know as much as possible before you get into the hearing room so that you are comfortable and able to fully participate in the proceedings. Below are two ways you can learn about the hearing process so that you can prepare for the big day.

Know What Questions to Expect
You may be more comfortable if you know what kinds of questions to expect during the hearing. The administrative law judge will likely ask you for your name, Social Security number, age, mailing address, height and weight. After that, you should be prepared to answer questions such as:

What is your formal education?
Do you have any vocational training?
Are you currently working?
What was your last job and what were your job responsibilities?
Have you tried working since you became disabled?
Where else have you worked in the last 15 years and what were your job responsibilities?
What is your diagnosis?
What treatments have you tried?
Do your treatments have any side effects?
How does your disability impact your daily activities?
How does your disability impact your ability to take care of yourself?
How long can you sit, stand, or walk without needing a break?
How much can you lift?
How often do you need to take breaks?
Do you have any issues getting along with supervisors, co-workers, clients, or customers?
Do you have any difficulties concentrating or remembering things?
Not every question will be asked at your hearing, but it is important to be prepared and to know how to answer the questions that pertain to your disability before you walk into the hearing room.

Work With a Lawyer Who Will Thoroughly Prepare You for Your Hearing
Our board certified Social Security disability lawyers will not let you go to your hearing unprepared. We will use our experience to anticipate what the administrative law judge wants to know and to help you anticipate the questions that will be asked of you so that you can prepare your answers.

To learn more about how to prepare for a Social Security disability hearing, please contact us at any time via this website or phone.

BIG_BLOG.TITLE: Three Tips For Getting Your Social Security Disability Application Approved If You Suffer From Hemophilia
BIG_BLOG.CONTENT:
Not everyone who suffers from hemophilia is going to qualify for Social Security disability benefits. In order to get the benefits you deserve, you are going to have to submit a convincing application to the Social Security Administration that proves you qualify for such benefits.

How to Submit a Strong Application
Social Security disability applications must be filled out honestly and convincingly. If there is any doubt about the severity of your medical condition or about any aspect of your application, your request for disability benefits will be denied. You can help prevent this from happening to you by:

Making sure you are organized and prepared before you submit an application. You want to have all of the information you need to fill out your application ready before you begin filling it out. This includes, but is not limited to, information about your work history, prior hospitalizations, and how your hemophilia is impacting your activities of daily living.
Submitting the right medical evidence. People with mild hemophilia are not going to qualify for benefits. Accordingly, medical tests, observations, and treatments are going to be considered as part of your disability application. While evidence from any doctor may be considered, documentation from your hematologist may be especially convincing.
Working with an experienced Social Security disability lawyer. There are many details that, together, make a convincing Social Security disability application. A board certified lawyer can make sure that all of the relevant details are included in your application and that all of your rights are protected as you apply for these important benefits.
These three steps may seem simple, but they can mean the difference between having a disability application approved and having to appeal a denied application. Accordingly, we encourage you to follow these three tips and to learn more about your rights before you submit your application. You can get started right now, for free, by downloading a complimentary copy of our book, Social Security Disability: What You Need to Know.

BIG_BLOG.TITLE: The Importance Of Your Doctor’s Opinion To Your Social Security Disability Claim
BIG_BLOG.CONTENT:
Why Your Doctor’s Opinion Counts & How to Obtain It

In a claim for Social Security disability benefits, it may seem like the Social Security Administration is getting the opinion of every doctor but your own.  Social Security will often obtain the opinions of their own consultative doctors, who only examine you once. They may also ask doctors who have never examined you to describe your work-related limitations based only on the paper medical records in your file.

So, where does YOUR doctor’s opinion fit into all of this? Does Social Security even have to consider what your own doctor says?

The answer is yes! Social Security’s own regulations and rulings provide that if your treating doctor offers an opinion about what you can and cannot do in the workplace, the person deciding your case must consider what your doctor says.  In fact, Social Security’s rules state that usually, your doctor’s opinion should be given greater weight than the opinion of a doctor who has not treated you.  Also, the longer that doctor has treated you, the more weight it will generally be given.  This means your doctor’s opinion about your limitations can make a big impact on your case.

What is the best way to get your doctor’s opinion? At Morgan & Weisbrod, we will usually create customized forms, called Interrogatories or Medical Source Statements, for your doctor to complete. These forms are basically questionnaires aimed at getting the most essential information about your limitations from your doctor.  For example, if you have severe back pain, we might ask your doctor how long you can stand, walk and sit, and whether it’s medically necessary for you to lie down several hours a day to alleviate pain.  Or, for instance, if you struggle with mental impairments like depression or anxiety, we will ask your psychiatrist or psychologist how often  you experience difficulty concentrating, whether you can follow complex versus simple instructions, and whether you can be expected to interact appropriately with co-workers, supervisors, and the public. Usually, we will mail these forms to you and ask that you take them to your doctor to be completed.

Often, the challenging part is ensuring that your doctor completes the forms.  We cannot force your doctor to do this. Sometimes, treating doctors are hesitant to complete forms for various reasons. However, there are some points you can make to your doctor if he or she is reluctant to help. If you encounter this problem, keep the following talking points in mind:

     *Explain that your doctor’s opinion can make a big difference in your Social Security disability case. It might even make the difference between winning and losing your claim.
     *If your doctor tells you that your lawyer already has his/her treatment notes and that should be enough information, politely disagree. Explain that their treatment notes do not necessarily discuss all of the functional limitations addressed in the forms. For example, do their notes indicate how much weight you can lift or how long you can sit, stand, or walk? Often, they do not address those details.
     *If your doctor says you need to see a “disability doctor” or have a functional capacity evaluation (“FCE”) performed, tell them that under Social Security’s rules, this is not required. In fact, it’s much more helpful to get your doctor’s opinion, based on multiple office visits, than to go to a doctor who will only evaluate you once.*Explain that your doctor need not perform any additional examinations; his or her answers can be based on his or her knowledge of your conditions and treatment history.*Tell your doctor that if you win your disability case, you will start receiving either Medicaid or Medicare. Many doctors are unaware of this fact. However, once they learn this, they sometimes see the “big picture” and realize that winning this claim is not just about the monthly dollar benefits, but also about obtaining regular (and often better) medical attention through the Medicaid or Medicare program.If your doctor agrees that you cannot work, the best thing he/she can do to help you win your case is answer a few simple questions about your limitations. Making this small effort will help the judge understand exactly how your conditions keep you from working.

BIG_BLOG.TITLE: Five Things You Need To Know Before Seeking Social Security Disability Benefits For A Bullous Disease
BIG_BLOG.CONTENT:
You are suffering. Your medical condition may have affected your range of motion or fluid filled blisters may have developed on the palms of your hands, the soles of your feet, or your perineum/groin area and even the simplest of tasks may be difficult. Social Security disability may be an option for you if you are unable to work, but before you apply there are some things that you should know.

    Be Prepared Before You Apply for Social Security Disability Benefits
    Before you submit an application, it is important to know that:
    
    1. There Are Multiple Conditions That Are Considered Bullous Diseases
    According to the Merck Manual bullous diseases include, but are not limited to:
    
    Bullous pemphigoid
    Dermatitis herpetiformis
    Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita
    Linear Immunoglobulin A disease
    Mucous membrane pemphigoid
    Pemphigus foliaceus
    Pemphigus vulgaris
    These conditions all have one thing in common: they result in raised and fluid-filled blisters that are greater than or equal to 10 mm in diameter. These blisters are known as bullae.
    
    2. Bullous Diseases Are Included in the Social Security Administration’s Listing of Impairments
    If you have a bullous disease and you meet the requirements in Section 8.03 in the Listing of Impairments, you will qualify for Social Security disability benefits. In order to qualify pursuant to this listing, you need a diagnosis and you must have extensive skin lesions that persist for at least three months despite your compliance with a prescribed treatment plan.
    
    3. You Need Certain Evidence to Submit With Your Application
    It is important to provide the Social Security Administration with information about your condition. This includes, but may not be limited to:
    
    A description of your lesions. This should include their sizes, locations, and information about how long you’ve had them.
    Impact of your lesions. The Social Security Administration will want to know how your lesions impact your activities of daily living and your ability to work.
    Medical test findings that confirm your diagnosis. This could include, for example, biopsy results.
    The idea is to provide honest and accurate information about your medical condition to the Social Security Administration for its consideration.
    
    4. Your Treatment Is Important
    Unless you have a good reason for foregoing medical treatment, you cannot receive Social Security disability benefits until you demonstrate that you have complied with your doctor’s treatment plan. Treatments for bullous diseases may include different medications such as anti-inflammatories, corticosteroids, or medications to suppress the immune system.
    
    5. A Social Security Disability Lawyer Can Help You
    Applying for Social Security disability benefits can be tricky. If any part of your application is incomplete or unclear, your application can be denied. An experienced Social Security disability lawyer can help prevent this from happening to you. Please contact us today via this website or by phone to schedule an initial consultation with one of our board certified lawyers so that we can talk about getting you the benefits you deserve.

BIG_BLOG.TITLE: Executive Sponsorship: A Case Study
BIG_BLOG.CONTENT:
Executive Sponsorship
Transforming a Stalled ERP Implementation into a Resounding Success  
In the rapidly evolving landscape of law and accounting firms, effective project management and streamlined operations are paramount. Morvay Consulting Group, led by Jacob Morvay, specializes in rescuing and revitalizing complex projects that have gone off track using the Executive Sponsorship model of project management. This case study showcases the successful turnaround of a stalled ERP implementation utilizing the Executive Sponsorship method.

Background
The firm had embarked on an ambitious project to upgrade its ERP system from a legacy platform in place for over 10 years to a new platform, while also implementing a new paperless billing solution. However, midway through, the project had come to a complete halt, with work paused indefinitely. The situation was dire, with multiple challenges threatening the project's success.

Challenges
Despite having strong support from firm leadership, the project had stalled. The first step was to determine why.

Team Dynamics
The project team was understaffed, and existing team members were not collaborating effectively. People were worried about individual consequences for bad decisions versus overall project success.

Vendor Relationships
The project relied heavily on third party vendor support to implement the solution. The vendor relationships had deteriorated due to changing timelines and targets. The vendors did not trust the team, and the team did not trust the vendors.

Written Plan and Goals
There was no formal project plan specifying key deadlines, deliverables, and goals. Individual teams were working on different parts of the project without a view to the overall goals, because they were not clearly established.

Approach
By focusing on bringing people together to work towards a common goal, while ensuring they had the resources to be successful, the project began to turn around.

Listening and Understanding
The first step was to ask open questions and listen to the concerns of different groups within the firm. The approach for the internal finance team was a focus on team building, encouraging mutual support and collaboration. For the HR and IT teams, the start was to assess their level of  integration with the project and quickly establish strong working relationships with the other teams, fostering a collaborative environment.

By pausing the project to reassess the situation, engaging with all vendors to understand their perspectives, and adjusting vendor relationships as needed, the firm developed a comprehensive project plan with stakeholder buy-in.

Engaging Leadership
The team worked closely with the firm’s attorney leadership to define what success would look like and helped them understand the additional financial investments needed. By collaborating with them to develop a clear communication strategy, the firm ensured all stakeholders were informed and aligned.

Leadership moved to a role of supporting the project as cheerleaders and enforcers, rather than getting involved in daily decisions. It was impressed upon leadership the importance of using the solutions themselves to set an example.

Building Culture and Collaboration
Team members were identified into three groups: proactive supporters of the project, persuadable adversaries, and active resistors. Clear expectations were set for all groups, and the project teams were balanced to include both supporters and persuadable adversaries. Resistors were coached  to adopt the necessary changes. 

The firm created clear roles and responsibilities within the team, with a robust structure to raise concerns and objections. This allowed team members to feel heard and valued. The firm assigned specific team members to particular parts of the project, significantly increasing their independent decision-making authority. They empowered those closest to the functions to lead decision-making, ensuring the best outcomes for the project.

Defining Success
The firm set clear and measurable goals for the team as a whole, and for individual contributors. This helped team members understand their role within the project while also focusing on the larger institutional goals. Having defined goals allows team members to self-assess, increasing confidence.

Building Trust and Engagement
The firm instituted regular meetings for managers and their teams, provided opportunities for junior members to take on bigger roles, and ensured continuous feedback. They  organized social activities to foster personal connections among team members, and encouraged open communication, promoting a culture of experimentation and support.

To trust in others, you must first trust yourself. It was essential to conduct an honest assessments of team members' skills relative to their roles and brought in third-party help to supplement and support areas where internal capabilities were lacking.

Technology and Vendor Adjustments
The firm replaced the outdated paperless billing solution with a new vendor offering a proactive partnership and a superior product. They used the feedback from project vendors to change the approach and better utilize their skills,  which was one of the major contributors to finishing the project under budget.

Results
The ERP implementation and the firm-wide launch of paperless billing were completed 9 months ahead of the original schedule. The new paperless billing solution improved the efficiency and speed of client billing, leading to a record high billing and collection year for the firm.

Measuring Success
There are many ways to measure success; meeting your project goals is just one of them. In addition to going live ahead of schedule and under budget, the firm recognized longer-term cultural change that ensured strong overall adoption.

Stakeholder Advocacy
Many skeptical partners became advocates through understanding their concerns and addressing them effectively. As a result, they became advocates of the new system. Strong senior leadership from the firm’s attorney leaders was integral to the partner adoption.

Team Culture Transformation
The team developed a strong sense of ownership, knowing that their collaborative efforts were crucial to the project’s success. There was a noticeable improvement in interpersonal relationships and enhanced collaboration, both within the finance function and across the firm, which continued after the project ended.

Conclusion
The firm had embarked on an ambitious project to upgrade its ERP system from a legacy platform in place for over 10 years to a new platform, while also implementing a new paperless billing solution. However, midway through, the project had come to a complete halt, with work paused indefinitely. The situation was dire, with multiple challenges threatening the project's success.

How to Navigate the Legal Process of VC Investments: A Guide for Startups




Securing venture capital (VC) investment can be a game-changer for startups, but it's crucial to understand the legal intricacies involved. The process typically begins with a term sheet, which outlines the key terms of the investment. As a startup founder, it's essential to carefully review this document with your legal counsel to ensure your interests are protected.


Once the term sheet is agreed upon, the next step is due diligence. VCs will scrutinize your company's financials, intellectual property, and corporate structure. Prepare for this by organizing all relevant documents and addressing any potential legal issues beforehand. Remember, transparency is key during this phase, as it builds trust with your potential investors and can help streamline the investment process.

The Legal Essentials of VC Investment Agreements: What You Need to Know




When finalizing a VC investment, several key legal documents come into play. The Stock Purchase Agreement is the primary contract that outlines the terms of the investment, including the number of shares being sold and at what price. Alongside this, you'll likely encounter Investor Rights Agreements, which detail the rights of the new investors, such as information rights and board representation.


Another crucial document is the Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation, which reflects the new capital structure post-investment. It's also common to have Right of First Refusal and Co-Sale Agreements, protecting both the company and investors in future stock sales. As a startup founder, it's vital to work closely with your legal team to understand these documents and negotiate terms that align with your company's long-term vision and goals.

How to Protect Your Interests in VC Funding Rounds: Legal Strategies for Founders




As a founder seeking VC funding, it's crucial to protect your interests throughout the investment process. Start by clearly defining your company's valuation and the amount of equity you're willing to give up. Be prepared to negotiate these points, as they will significantly impact your control and future earnings. It's also wise to include anti-dilution provisions in your agreements to protect your stake in future funding rounds.


Consider implementing vesting schedules for founder shares to demonstrate your long-term commitment to the company. This can also help attract investors by aligning your interests with theirs. Lastly, pay close attention to control provisions in the investment agreements. While investors will want a say in major decisions, it's important to maintain enough control to effectively run your company. Remember, the goal is to create a balanced partnership that benefits both your startup and the investors.

Ethical Considerations for Using Generative AI: Navigating the Complex Landscape

As generative AI continues to revolutionize various industries, it's crucial to address the ethical implications that arise from its widespread adoption. This powerful technology, capable of creating human-like text, images, and even code, brings with it a host of ethical considerations that demand our attention and careful navigation.

Transparency and Accountability

One of the primary ethical concerns surrounding generative AI is the need for transparency and accountability. Users should be fully aware of when they're interacting with AI-generated content, and organizations deploying these systems must be open about their capabilities and limitations. This transparency extends to the algorithms and data used to train these models, ensuring that stakeholders can understand and scrutinize the decision-making processes.

Accountability measures are equally important. Clear guidelines and protocols should be established to address any unintended consequences or harmful outputs produced by generative AI systems. This includes designating responsible parties within organizations and creating mechanisms for redress when issues arise.

Bias and Fairness

Generative AI models are only as unbiased as the data they're trained on, and unfortunately, this data often reflects societal biases and prejudices. It's essential to implement rigorous testing and monitoring processes to identify and mitigate biases in AI-generated content. This includes ensuring that these systems do not perpetuate or amplify discrimination based on protected characteristics such as race, gender, age, or disability.

Organizations must invest in diverse teams to develop and oversee these AI systems, bringing a range of perspectives to the table and helping to identify potential biases that might otherwise go unnoticed.

Privacy and Data Protection

The development of generative AI often requires vast amounts of data, raising significant privacy concerns. It's crucial to implement robust data protection measures to safeguard personal information and prevent unauthorized access or misuse. This includes adhering to data protection regulations such as GDPR and CCPA, as well as implementing best practices for data anonymization and encryption.

Moreover, organizations must be transparent about their data collection and usage practices, obtaining informed consent from individuals whose data may be used to train or improve AI models.

Ethical Consideration

Key Actions

Transparency

Disclose AI use, explain capabilities and limitations

Bias Mitigation

Implement testing, monitoring, and diverse team oversight

Data Protection

Adhere to regulations, implement security measures

Informed Consent and User Autonomy

Respecting user autonomy is paramount when deploying generative AI systems. Users should be clearly informed when they are interacting with AI-generated content or AI-powered systems. This transparency allows individuals to make informed decisions about their engagement with these technologies and maintains trust between users and organizations.

Additionally, users should have control over their data and how it's used in AI systems. This includes the right to opt-out of data collection or to request the deletion of their personal information from AI training datasets.

Responsible Content Generation

Generative AI has the potential to produce content at an unprecedented scale and speed. However, this capability comes with the risk of generating harmful, misleading, or unethical content. Organizations must implement robust content moderation systems and ethical guidelines to prevent the creation and dissemination of inappropriate or dangerous material.

This includes developing AI models with built-in safeguards against generating hate speech, explicit content, or disinformation. Regular audits and human oversight should be employed to ensure that the AI-generated content aligns with ethical standards and organizational values.

Environmental and Energy Impacts

The development and deployment of large-scale generative AI models can have significant environmental implications due to their high computational requirements. Organizations should consider the energy consumption and carbon footprint associated with training and running these models.

Efforts should be made to optimize AI systems for energy efficiency and to utilize renewable energy sources where possible. Additionally, the long-term environmental impact of AI technologies should be factored into decision-making processes when implementing these systems.

Alignment with Human Values

As generative AI becomes more sophisticated, ensuring that these systems align with human values and ethical principles becomes increasingly important. This involves not only programming AI to follow ethical guidelines but also fostering a culture of ethical AI development within organizations.

Regular ethical assessments should be conducted to evaluate the impact of AI systems on society, human rights, and social norms. Organizations should also engage with diverse stakeholders, including ethicists, policymakers, and community representatives, to ensure that AI development aligns with broader societal values.

Governance and Oversight

Establishing robust governance frameworks is essential for the responsible development and deployment of generative AI. This includes creating internal ethical review boards, implementing regular audits, and adhering to industry best practices and emerging regulations.

Organizations should also participate in broader discussions about AI governance, contributing to the development of industry standards and regulatory frameworks that promote ethical AI use.

Conclusion

As generative AI continues to advance, addressing these ethical considerations becomes increasingly crucial. Organizations must take a proactive approach to ensure that their use of generative AI aligns with ethical principles and societal values. By prioritizing transparency, fairness, privacy, and responsible development, we can harness the power of generative AI while mitigating potential risks and negative impacts.

Estate planning is a crucial aspect of financial management that often gets overlooked. It's not just for the wealthy; everyone can benefit from having a well-thought-out estate plan. This legal process involves arranging for the management and disposal of your assets in the event of incapacitation or death, ensuring your wishes are carried out and your loved ones are protected.

Navigating Texas Probate: Key Tips for Executors




As an executor of an estate in Texas, understanding the probate process is crucial. One key tip is to file the will with the probate court within four years of the decedent's death. This timeline is essential, as failing to do so may result in the estate being treated as if there was no will, potentially complicating the distribution of assets.


Another important tactic is to properly notify all potential heirs and beneficiaries. Texas law requires executors to send notice to all named beneficiaries in the will, as well as to any heirs who would inherit if there was no will. This step helps prevent future disputes and ensures a smoother probate process.

Simplifying Probate in Texas: Small Estate Affidavits




For smaller estates in Texas, utilizing a Small Estate Affidavit can be a time and cost-effective alternative to full probate. This option is available when the total value of the estate, excluding homestead and exempt property, is $75,000 or less. It's a valuable tool for streamlining the process and reducing administrative burdens.


To use this tactic effectively, ensure that all statutory requirements are met. This includes having all distributees sign the affidavit and obtaining a court order approving it. Remember, this method can't be used if the deceased left a will or if there's real estate involved other than a homestead. When applicable, it can significantly simplify the probate process.

Texas Probate Strategy: Independent Administration




One of the most beneficial tactics in Texas probate law is opting for Independent Administration. This approach allows the executor to manage the estate with minimal court supervision, saving time and reducing costs. To implement this strategy, the will must specifically allow for independent administration, or all beneficiaries must agree to it.


As an independent executor, you have more freedom in managing the estate, but it's crucial to maintain accurate records and act in the best interest of the beneficiaries. This includes proper asset valuation, debt payment, and timely distribution of assets. While this method offers flexibility, it's still wise to consult with a probate attorney to ensure all legal obligations are met throughout the process.

While probate is common in Texas, there are several alternatives that can simplify the process of transferring assets after death. One effective tactic is the use of small estate affidavits for estates valued under $75,000. This method allows for a quicker and less expensive transfer of assets without going through full probate proceedings, making it ideal for smaller estates.


Another valuable tip is to consider creating a living trust. In Texas, assets held in a properly funded living trust can bypass probate entirely, offering a private and often faster way to distribute assets to beneficiaries. This strategy not only saves time and money but also provides greater control over asset distribution and can be particularly beneficial for larger or more complex estates.

Probate Law in Texas: Key Deadlines and Time Management




Effective time management is crucial when dealing with probate in Texas. A vital tip is to be aware of the 90-day deadline for filing an inventory, appraisement, and list of claims with the court after being appointed as an executor. This document provides a comprehensive overview of the estate's assets and liabilities, and failing to meet this deadline can result in removal as executor.


Another important tactic is to promptly notify creditors of the estate. In Texas, you have one month to publish a notice to creditors in a local newspaper and four months to directly notify known secured creditors. Adhering to these timelines is essential for properly managing the estate's debts and avoiding personal liability as an executor. Staying organized and meeting these deadlines will help ensure a smooth probate process in Texas.

This streamlined approach can save time and money, making it an invaluable tool for Texas probate attorneys and beneficiaries alike.

Missing this deadline can significantly complicate the process and may require additional legal procedures.


Another key deadline is the inventory, appraisement, and list of claims, which must be filed within 90 days of the executor's appointment. Executors should also be aware that creditors must be notified within 60 days of the executor's appointment. Keeping these deadlines in mind can help ensure a smooth probate process and avoid potential legal complications.

BIG_BLOG.TITLE: DACA RECIPIENTS: GREEN CARD THROUGH MARRIAGE OR EMPLOYMENT
BIG_BLOG.CONTENT:
Blog DACA Recipients: Green Card through Marriage or Employment

CAN SOMEONE ON DACA APPLY FOR A GREEN CARD?
DACA is not a lawful status. But that doesn’t mean that someone with DACA cannot get a green card. DACA applicants’ pathway to a green card depends on their application basis.

There is a big difference between someone on DACA applying for a green card through marriage versus through employment. This article will look at the two different paths:

OBTAINING A MARRIAGE-BASED GREEN CARD
The method by which the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals recipient entered the US is relevant in determining whether someone can apply for a green card in the US (known as adjustment of status) or outside of the US (Consular processing). 

DACA recipients who entered the country lawfully can apply for adjustment of status by filing Form I-485. They must have been inspected and admitted by a CBP officer and be married to a USC.  Those married to an LPR cannot file for adjustment, irrespective of whether they have a lawful entry. 

DACA recipients that entered the U.S. unlawfully are not allowed to adjust in the U.S. and must go for Consular processing.  This is because a lawful entry is required to file for adjustment of status. This means leaving the U.S. after the I-130 is approved and going to the U.S. Consulate in their home country to obtain an Immigrant Visa.  Once the Immigrant Visa is used to return to the U.S. the applicant will receive his/her green card. 

However, this is where it gets more complicated. Applicants with over 180 days but less than one year of unlawful presence face a 3-year bar upon leaving the U.S. Those with a year or more of unlawful presence face a 10-year bar. 

DACA recipients who received DACA prior to their 18th birthday do not accrue any lawful presence. People who get DACA after turning 18 will have an unlawful presence. Calculate days from the 18th birthday to receiving DACA as DACA prevents the accrual of unlawful presence. 

Exploring the pathway to a green card is crucial for DACA recipients seeking to adjust their immigration status.

THE BOARD OF IMMIGRATION APPEALS
A Board of Immigration Appeals (BIA) decision, Matter of Arabally and Yerrabelly states that someone who travels using advance parole (travel document) does not make a departure from the U.S. and therefore does not trigger the 3- or 10-year bar.   

Someone on DACA with accrued unlawful presence can leave on advance parole. They can return to the US legally and file for adjustment of status if married to a USC. 

If you entered unlawfully and stayed over 180 days without a way to get advance parole, leaving the US will activate the 3- or 10-year bar. However, you may be eligible for a waiver to overcome the bar if you can show extreme hardship to a USC/LPR spouse or parent.   

OBTAINING AN EMPLOYMENT-BASED GREEN CARD
While DACA recipients can be sponsored by their employer for a green card they cannot apply to adjust their status in the US because DACA is not a lawful status. Employment-based adjustment needs lawful nonimmigrant status to file. An applicant with advance parole cannot adjust status for an employment-based green card upon legal re-entry to the US. because DACA is not a valid status. 

DACA recipients who got DACA before 18 and have no unlawful presence can get a green card by attending a US Consulate appointment.  The 3- or 10-year bar is not triggered. 

If you obtained DACA after turning 18 and therefore you have an unlawful presence, then leaving the U.S. will trigger the bar. In Matter of Arabally and Yerrabelly, using advance parole does not trigger the 3- or 10-year bar. Someone traveling with advance parole does not leave the U.S.  The problem here is that although USCIS recognizes this as a matter of law, DOS does not.  This question has been raised with DOS, and they have failed to answer this. A DACA recipient with unlawful presence will still struggle to get an employment-based green card.

Exploring the pathway to a green card is essential for DACA recipients aiming for employment-based immigration opportunities.

Conclusion 

To transition from DACA to a Green Card, consult an Immigration Attorney.  If you have questions regarding any of the above, please contact PLG Partner cprescott@patellegal.com.

BIG_BLOG.TITLE: THE VISA BULLETIN EXPLAINED: UNDERSTANDING THE EB-5 CATEGORIES PRE AND POST RIA
BIG_BLOG.CONTENT:
Posted on Mar 12, 2024 by Rakesh Patel and Jacqueline Trevino
        
        Blog The Visa Bulletin Explained: Understanding the EB-5 Categories Pre and Post RIA
        
        The visa bulletin is a monthly publication issued by the US Department of State that provides information on the availability of immigrant visas. It categorizes applicants based on their priority date and country of birth, determining when they can proceed with applying for a green card. On the visa bulletin, the 5th preference category refers to the EB-5 Immigrant Investor Program. There are two main EB-5 categories on the visa bulletin: the unreserved categories and set aside categories.  
        
        Unreserved Category 
        
        The unreserved category is for investments made before the enactment of the Reform and Integrity Act (RIA) in 2022 or subsequent investments post-RIA that do not meet the criteria for the visa set aside categories. This category relates to investments of $1,050,000 and is not subject to specific allocation percentages.  
        
        In April 2024, the unreserved categories will remain current for all countries with the exception of China and India. For a green card application to move forward, investors from China must have the priority date of December 15, 2015, or earlier, while investors from India must have a priority date of December 01, 2020, or earlier. Furthermore, it is taking approximately two to three years to receive conditional green card status for these types of projects. 
        
        Set Aside Categories   
        
        The set asides are listed in three distinct rows, each indicating the percentage of the EB-5 visas that are set aside for each category each fiscal year. These categories include visas set asides for rural projects (20%), high unemployment projects (10%), and infrastructure projects (2%), all requiring an investment of at least $800,000. 
        
        Any of the set aside visas that go unused are held within the same category for the following fiscal year. If there are remaining unused visas in these categories after the second fiscal year, they are released to the unreserved categories during the third fiscal year. 
        
        In April 2024, the set aside categories will remain current for all countries. No specific priority date is required for an investor currently in the US on a valid status to concurrently file Form I-526 or I-526E along with Form I-485 to initiate their adjustment of status to a conditional green card holder. Furthermore, these post-RIA investments are experiencing notably faster processing times in comparison to the unreserved category, with some investors receiving their conditional green card as fast as 12 to 18 months.  
        
        To learn more about the EB-5 visa set aside categories or concurrent filing, please visit our blog site at https://patellegal.com/blog/category/immigration-blog/. 
        
        If you have any questions regarding the EB-5 process or your place in line for a green card, please email us at rpatel@patellegal.com and jtrevino@patellegal.com.

BIG_BLOG.TITLE: CONCURRENT FILING SPARKS INCREASED INTEREST IN THE EB-5 PROGRAM
BIG_BLOG.CONTENT:
The EB-5 Reform and Integrity Act (RIA) of 2022 authorizes certain new investors to file a Form I-485 (Application for Adjustment of Status) along with a Form I-526 (Immigrant Petition by Standalone Investor) or Form I-526E (Immigrant Petition by Regional Center Investor). This is called concurrent filing, and to take advantage of it, there must be a visa available for the applicant, and the applicant must reside in the U.S. in a nonimmigrant status that is eligible for adjustment of status. If a visa is available, it indicates there is space within the annual quota set by the U.S. government for EB-5 immigrant investors to proceed with their visa application process. This is evidenced by the visa category being listed as “Current” in the U.S. Department of State visa bulletin, which displays the availability of immigrant visas each month. 

        The provision for concurrent filing is advantageous for eligible individuals. By submitting an I-485 application for adjustment of status, investors can seek work authorization and advance parole documents. These documents allow lawful employment and international travel during the pendency of both the I-526 petition and adjustment of status application. 
        
        As of January 2024, the set-aside EB-5 categories are classified as “Current” for all countries, meaning an EB-5 investor need not have a particular priority date (the date they filed their application) for a visa to be available to them. Thus, if an investor invests the minimum requirement of $800,000.00 USD in a rural, high unemployment, or infrastructure project, they can move forward with their immigration application process. This is particularly notable for China and India, the only countries whose unreserved EB-5 categories remain uncurrent. 
        
        The option to concurrently file is one of the provisions that makes the reformed program more effective and appealing to foreign investors residing in the U.S. on a nonimmigrant visa. It enables applicants to remain in the U.S. and avoid lengthy processing times. For example, it may take USCIS up to 56.5 months to process the I-526 petition and 49 months to process the I-485 petition. However, USCIS often processes the I-485 application shortly after approving the I-526 petition. Nonetheless, it is recommended to maintain nonimmigrant status until a conditional green card is approved. 
        
        We encourage Indian and Chinese nationals to take advantage of this provision while the priority dates remain current.
